in Germany presented their research

the protein hemocyanin which carries
oxygen and octopus blood it's basically
the octopus version of hemoglobin and it
contains copper which is why octopus
blood is blue the biologists compared
hemocyanin and octopi living in sub zero
degrees celsius oceans in Antarctica to
that of octopi living in temperate and
warm waters and it turns out that
hemocyanin acts differently in sub-zero
temperatures than it does in warmer
waters in cold water hemocyanin goes
into overdrive supplying oxygen to body
tissues keeping the animal healthy and
lightening the load for the octopuses
three hearts which have to work harder
in oxygen-rich cold waters yes
octopuses have three hearts the total
package means that octopi get to hang
out in bitterly cold waters which is
nice because they live short lives and
can't migrate very far so if an

and apparently evolution has met that

around five thousand years ago people
around the Ganges Delta in Bangladesh
developed genes that allowed them to
survive cholera the Ganges Delta is the
wettest part of the wettest country in
the world and cholera the bacterium
vibrio cholerae loves water via water
the cholera bacterium infects the small
intestines and releases a toxin that
causes severe diarrhea dehydration and
until modern medicine usually death so
yeah avoiding that would have been a
pretty useful adaptation researchers
studied the genomes of 42 Bangladeshi
families picked at random and found five
thousand-year-old variants on genes that
helped regulate water loss in the
intestines as well as on genes that
regulate immune responses to infections
then they looked at samples from more
than 200 Bangladeshis who were sick with
cholera they identified five especially
common gene variants that when exposed
to the cholera toxin in a lab triggered
the production of proteins that aid in
fighting infections having stuck around
for like five thousand years it's likely
that these variants are part of the
reason why some people with cholera were
able to survive long enough to
reproduce and that's all evolution
